JS Injection Example¶

Flask Server¶

Server for JS Injection example

Contains a minimal implementation of a server.

src.flask_server.server.hello_name(name)[source]¶

A simple hello function, using a param

Parameters

name (str) – The name of the person/thing to greet

Returns

‘Hello <name>’

Return type

str

src.flask_server.server.hello_world()[source]¶

A hello world function

Returns

“Hello world!”

Return type

str

Database¶

A simple module we use to store data temporally.

Currently using sqlite3. Sqlite3 comes with a :memory: param that creates the DB in RAM memory, but this is not used because Flask is multithreaded, and sqlite cursors cannot be shared among threads!

src.flask_server.mydb.close(conn)[source]¶

Closes the given connection connection.

Parameters

conn – A sqlite3.connection.

src.flask_server.mydb.connect()[source]¶

Connects to the DB.

Returns

(sqlite3.connection, sqlite3.connection.cursor)

src.flask_server.mydb.delete()[source]¶

Deletes the database from the file system. This is a workaround for an in-memory database.

src.flask_server.mydb.get_all(c)[source]¶

Gets all rows from the “posts” table.

Parameters

c – A cursor to a sqlite3 database.

Returns

list(row).

src.flask_server.mydb.initialize()[source]¶

Initializes the DB, creating tables and inserting necessary rows.

src.flask_server.mydb.new_post(c, data)[source]¶

Insers a “post” in the database.

Parameters

  • c – A cursor to a sqlite3 database.

  • data – Values of the row to insert.
